Luis Rodriguez

Software Engineer // Chemical Engineer // Data Scientist

-

About Myself

I am currently a student at The Johns Hopkins University majoring in Chemical and Biomolecular Engineering while minoring in Computer Science. Throughout my college career I have had the opportunity to work as a Quality Assurance Specialist, a Research and Development intern and most recently, a Software Engineer at the Applied Physics Laboratory. I am a Big Data, deep learning, and machine learning enthusiast and most of my work revolves around the topic. In this website you can find some of the current projects (both professional and recreational) that I am involved with.

Experience

The Johns Hopkins University

I was accepted to JHU to complete a bachelor's degree in Chemical and Biomolecular Engineering and a minor in Computational Medicine by May of 2018.

2014 - 2018

Quality Assurance Analyst

As a quality assurance analyst at the Integrated Imaging Center, I administered quality control testing on IIC Zeiss microscopes by developing VB scripts. I managed a satellite facility and provided hands-on microscope training for new users.

May 2015 - May 2016

Research and Development Intern

As a research and develpment intern at the Diabetes Research Institute, I co-designed and assembled a high perfusion device, using 3D CAD, 3D printing techniques and Python and MATLAB coding languages. I also completed a user-manual and code for a MATLAB progrram designed to measure sarcomere displacement in heart contractions.

Summer 2016

Software Engineering Intern

As a Software Engineering intern at the Applied Physics Laboratory I extended a Python package that parallelizes common data access workflows to allow for easy data transfer and analyses from different petascale databases through a single remote. I also developed a user web-based interface for a partner company using React-JS(front end) and FlaskApp (back end) to allow for easy big data access and data sharing between companies.

Summer 2017

Software Engineer

I am currently a software engineer at the Applied Physics Laboratory where I work with developing and maintaining a big-data storage cloud-based framework used to accumulate neuro TEM and SEM multidimensional image data. The service is estimated to hold 6 petabytes of data. I also contribute to the tiered architecture of an APL database by implementing AWS Glacier to store often unused data and automate neuroscience image data analysis processes using Machine Learning and Deep Learning.

August 2017 - Current
